entry.title: Pulsar Lightcurves
entry.summary: Energy-resolved lightcurves are calculated for a weak pulsar.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, 8 figures

entry.title: A search for counterparts of gamma-ray pulsars detected by the FERMI Large Area Telescope
entry.summary: This paper has been withdrawn.
entry.arxiv:comment: This paper has been withdrawn

entry.title: Comment on "Biases in the Quasar Mass-Luminosity Plane"
entry.summary: Comment on "Biases in the Quasar Mass-Luminosity Plane"
entry.arxiv:comment: Comment on Biases in the Quasar Mass-Luminosity Plane; 3 pages

entry.title: Recent Results of the ANTARES Neutrino Telescope
entry.summary: Some recent results of the ANTARES neutrino telescope are reviewed.
entry.arxiv:comment: Contribution to TAUP 2011, to be published in JPCS, 4 pages, 2 figures

entry.title: Parametrization of Crab pulsar spectrum
entry.summary: CRAB pulsar data has been parameterized by using exponential function or broken exponential function. we use non extensive form of exponential function to parameterize this data.

entry.title: Results from the IceCube Experiment - Neutrino 2012
entry.summary: Neutrino 2012 proceedings of recent results from the IceCube experiment.

entry.title: Recent results from the Pierre Auger Observatory
entry.summary: The results obtained after the first decade of operation of the Pierre Auger Observatory are reviewed.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proceedings X SILAFAE Medellin-2014

entry.title: Gamma-ray Bursts: Light on the distant Universe
entry.summary: Observations of a long-lasting Gamma-ray burst, one that has the brightest optical counterpart yet discovered, challenge theoretical understanding of these bursts but may enhance their usefulness as cosmic probes.
entry.arxiv:comment: News and Views article for Nature (Sept. 11, 2008)

entry.title: Dark Matter Annihilation Induced Gamma Ray Emission from Galaxy Cluster 1E0657-56
entry.summary: Based on minimal supersymmetric standard model, neutralino dark matter annihilation induced gamma ray emission from galaxy cluster 1E0657-56 is calculated. The merge of bullet-like subcluster with the main cluster is also investigated.

entry.title: Beaming Selection and SN-GRB-Jets Evolution
entry.summary: After a decade of Fireball reign there is a hope for thin collimated Jet to solve the Supernova-GRB mystery
entry.arxiv:comment: 8 pages, 10 figures; white pages 2009

entry.title: Techniques to study cosmic ray anisotropies
entry.summary: These lectures review some of the techniques used to analyze the arrival direction distribution of Cosmic Rays, and some relevant results on the field.
entry.arxiv:comment: To appear in the Proceedings of the Third School on Cosmic Rays and Astrophysics, Arequipa, Peru

entry.title: Search for cosmic neutrino point sources with the 5-line ANTARES telescope
entry.summary: This paper has been withdrawn due a problem with the estimation of background.
entry.arxiv:comment: This paper has been withdrawn due a problem with the estimation of background

entry.title: Astrophysics: Most distant cosmic blast seen
entry.summary: The most distant -ray burst yet sighted is the earliest astronomical object ever observed in cosmic history. This ancient beacon offers a glimpse of the little-known cosmic dark ages.
entry.arxiv:comment: Published in Nature News & Views

entry.title: Properties of Gamma Ray Bursts at different redshifts
entry.summary: GRBs are now detected up to z = 8.26 . We try to find differences, in their restframe properties, which could be related either to distance or to observing conditions.
entry.arxiv:comment: 6 pages 2009 Fermi Symposium eConf Proceedings C091122

entry.title: IceCube: Status and Results
entry.summary: This talk describes the complete IceCube neutrino telescope and summarizes some results obtained while the detector was under construction.
entry.arxiv:comment: 16 pages, 4 figures for Proceedings of the XIV International Workshop on Neutrino Telescopes, Venice, March, 2011

entry.title: Accretion Disc Theory since Shakura and Sunyaev
entry.summary: I briefly review the progress of accretion disc theory since the seminal paper of Shakura and Sunyaev.
entry.arxiv:comment: to appear in proceedings of `The Golden Age of Cataclysmic Variables', Memorie Societa' Astronomica Italiana, 2012 (F. Giovannelli and L. Sabau-Graziati eds.)

entry.title: Radiative Processes in High Energy Astrophysics
entry.arxiv:comment: 157 pages, 64 figures. Lecture notes for a university course

entry.title: High Energy Neutrino Telescopes in the Northern Hemisphere
entry.summary: We review the status and results of the high energy neutrino telescopes in the Northern Hemisphere, namely ANTARES and Baikal (NT200+).
entry.arxiv:comment: Contribution to VLvNT 2011, to be published in NIM A, 6 pages, 8 figures

entry.title: Do magnetars really exist?
entry.summary: It is shown that there are neither necessary nor sufficient properties to provide unambiguous evidence for including any object in the AXP/SGR class.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proceedings of IAUS 291 "Neutron Stars and Pulsars: Challenges and Opportunities after 80 years", J. van Leeuwen (ed.); 4 pages

entry.title: Positron decrement in AMS-02 compared to Pamela, due to solar cycle
entry.summary: We present a numerical simulation of cosmic ray transport in the heliosphere and show that AMS-02 should observe a decrease in the positron fraction above 40GeV compared to the fraction observed by PAMELA.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, 3 figures

entry.title: The Composition of Cosmic Rays at the Knee
entry.summary: Recent results on the composition of cosmic rays in the energy region from about 10^14 to 10^18 eV are reviewed.
entry.arxiv:comment: Invited talk, given at the Centenary Symposium 2012: Discovery of Cosmic Rays, June 2012, Denver

entry.title: Calculation of thermal conductivity coefficients for magnetized neutron star
entry.summary: The coefficients that determine the electron heat transfer and diffusion in the crust of neutron stars are calculated on the basis of a solution of the Boltzmann equation with allowance for degeneracy.

entry.title: Neutrino Absorption in the Earth, Neutrino Cross-Sections, and New Physics
entry.summary: Large neutrino telescopes can measure the neutrino-nucleon cross-section by studying neutrino absorption in the Earth.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages; white paper for Snowmass Cosmic Frontier process

entry.title: VERITAS contributions to CF6-A: Cosmic Rays, Gamma Rays and Neutrinos
entry.summary: This white paper describes the contributions of the VERITAS gamma-ray telescope array to the CF6-A subgroup of the 'Cosmic Frontier' working group, part of the Snowmass Community Summer Study 2013.

entry.title: The Extragalactic Background Light (EBL): A Probe of Fundamental Physics and a Record of Structure Formation in the Universe
entry.summary: A brief white paper discussing the connections between the Extragalactic Background Light (EBL) and fundamental physics through gamma-ray observations is provided.
entry.arxiv:comment: Input for Snowmass 2013

entry.title: Afterglow jet breaks, GeV photons and the electromagnetic model of short GRBs
entry.summary: We discuss three topics: (i) the dynamics of afterglow jet breaks; (ii) the origin of Fermi-LAT photons; (iii) the electromagnetic model of short GRBs
entry.arxiv:comment: Proceedings, GRB 2013, Huntsville Gamma-Ray Burst Symposium

entry.title: H.E.S.S. contributions to the 33rd International Cosmic Ray Conference (ICRC2013)
entry.summary: H.E.S.S. contributions to the proceedings of the 33rd International Cosmic Ray Conference (ICRC2013) in Rio de Janeiro (Brazil)
entry.arxiv:comment: Index of H.E.S.S. conference proceedings at the ICRC2013, Rio de Janeiro (Brazil)

entry.title: Pulsar Emission Spectrum
entry.summary: Emission spectrum is calculated for a weak axisymmetric pulsar. Also calculated are the observed spectrum, efficiency, and the observed efficiency. The underlying flow of electrons and positrons turns out to be curiously intricate.
entry.arxiv:comment: 7 pages, 7 figures

entry.title: Crab pulsar spectrum: a non-extensive approach
entry.summary: Non extensive statistical physics has been applied to various problems in physics including astrophysics. In this paper we explore the possibility of using non extensive approach to explain the recently observed pulsed $\gamma$-ray from Crab pulsar above 100 GeV observed by VERITAS $\gamma$-ray telescope.

entry.title: On the spherically-symmetric turbulent accretion
entry.summary: We analize the quasi-spherical accretion in the presence of axisymmetric vortex turbulence. It is shown that in this case the turbulence changes mainly the effective gravity potential but not the effective pressure.
entry.arxiv:comment: 7 pages, 4 figures, submitted to MNRAS

entry.title: Identification of 3.55 KeV line in the framework of standard physics
entry.summary: Identification of the X-ray 3.55 KeV line as a recombination line of $\pi^-$ tritium mesoatom is proposed. It has been shown that in principle it is possible to form such an atom under standard laboratory conditions, without bringing in new physics.

entry.title: Spectral and Timing Analysis of the Prompt Emission of Gamma Ray Bursts
entry.summary: A Thesis Submitted to the Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Mumbai for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy in Physics (supervisor: Prof. A. R. Rao)
entry.arxiv:comment: A Thesis on gamma-ray burst prompt emission analysis

entry.title: Generalised Maxwellian Equations and their Implications
entry.summary: We present a reformulation of Mawxell's equation and examine the consequence of this new formulation. We argue that studies of such diverse topics as magnetic monopole, magnetic recombination and magneto-genesis could benefit from the new formulation.

entry.title: Radio Detection of High Energy Neutrinos
entry.summary: This is a review on radio detection of high energy neutrinos.
entry.arxiv:comment: To be published as part of the volume Neutrino Astronomy -- Current Status, Future Prospects by World Scientific

entry.title: Solar Corona Thermal Background and Energy Spectrum of the Weak Solar Soft X-ray Bursts
entry.summary: The energy spectrum of the weak solar soft X-ray bursts are investigated using the data of the Interball project.

entry.title: Hints of new physics from stars
entry.summary: We review and update the current status of the observed anomalies in stellar cooling and their interpretation in terms of axions and axion like particles.
entry.arxiv:comment: Contributed to the proceedings of the 38th International Conference on High Energy Physics

entry.title: Fast Radio Bursts' emission mechanism: implication from localization
entry.summary: We argue that the localization of the Repeating FRB at $\sim 1$ Gpc excludes rotationally-powered type of radio emission (e.g., analogues of Crab's giant pulses coming from very young energetic pulsars) as the origin of FRBs.

entry.title: Yet another introduction to relativistic astrophysics
entry.summary: Late Winter Lecture Notes, Short Course (10 hours) of Relativistic Astrophysics held at the Department of Physics and Astronomy of the University of Padova, March 13-17, 2017.
entry.arxiv:comment: 132 pages. Revised according to comments and suggestions received

entry.title: Cosmic Rays, Gamma rays, Neutrinos and Gravitational Waves
entry.summary: This paper discusses the relation between the study of the fluxes of cosmic rays, gamma rays and neutrinos, and the connection of these observations with the newly born field of gravitational wave astronomy.
entry.arxiv:comment: 6 pages, 2 figures. Proceedings of workshop SCINEGHE 2016

entry.title: The relativistic equation of motion in turbulent jets
entry.summary: The turbulent jets are usually described by classical velocities. The relativistic case can be treated starting from the conservation of the relativistic momentum. The two key assumptions which allow to obtain a simple expression for the relativistic trajectory and relativistic velocity are null pressure and constant density.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 figures 7 pages

entry.title: Testing hadronic interaction packages at cosmic ray energies
entry.summary: A comparative analysis of the secondary particles output of the main hadronic interaction packages used in simulations of extensive air showers is presented. Special attention is given to the study of events with very energetic leading secondary particles, including diffractive interactions.

entry.title: Cosmic Accelerators
entry.summary: I discuss the scientific rationale and opportunities in the study of high energy particle accelerators away from the Earth; mostly, those outside the Solar System. I also briefly outline the features to be desired in telescopes used to probe accelerators studied by remote sensing.
entry.arxiv:comment: A White Paper submitted to the Astro 2010 Decadal Survey

entry.title: The search for extra-terrestrial sources of high energy neutrinos
entry.summary: The field of high-energy neutrino astronomy has seen rapid progress over the last 15 years, with the development and operation of the first large-volume detectors. Here, we review the motivation for construction of these large instruments and discuss what construction and physics progress has been made.
entry.arxiv:comment: Heavy Quarks and Leptons, Melbourne, 2008

entry.title: High Energy Phenomena In The Universe
entry.summary: Highlights of the 44th Rencontre De Moriond on High Energy Phenomena In The Universe which was held in La Thuile, Italy during February 1-8, 2009.
entry.arxiv:comment: Summary talk at the 44th Rencontre De Moriond on High Energy Phenomena In The Universe which was held in La Thuile, Italy during February 1-8, 2009

entry.title: Polarization from the oscillating magnetized accretion torus
entry.summary: We study oscillations of accretion torus with azimuthal magnetic field. For several lowest-order modes we calculate eigenfrequencies and eigenfunctions and calculate corresponding intensity and polarization light curves using advanced ray-tracing methods.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, 3 figures, Proceedings of the conference "The coming of age of X-ray polarimetry", Rome, Italy, 27-30 April 2009

entry.title: Stellar Sources of Gamma-Bursts
entry.summary: Our correlation analysis of Swift gamma-ray burst coordinates and nearby star locations (catalog Gliese) reveals 4 coincidences with angular accuracy better than 0.1 degree. The random probability is 2\times 10^{-4}, so evidencing that coincident stars are indeed gamma-ray burst sources. The fifth coincident gamma-burst could be added (angular accuracy 0.14 degree) with random probability for 5 events \sim 10^{-5}.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages

entry.title: Experimental Efforts on Very High-Energy Cosmic Rays and their Interactions - Conference Summary
entry.summary: Progress reported during the XV International Symposium on Very High-Energy Cosmic-Ray Interactions is summarized. Emphasize is given to experimental work. The actual status, recent results, and their implications on the present understanding of the origin of high-energy cosmic-rays and their interactions are discussed.
entry.arxiv:comment: Invited summary of the experimental efforts discussed at the XV ISVHECRI

entry.title: VERITAS Collaboration Contributions to the 31st International Cosmic Ray Conference
entry.summary: Index of the VERITAS contributions to ICRC 2009

entry.title: X-Ray Flares In GRB090812 - Case Study
entry.summary: The master formulae of the CB model of long durations gamma ray bursts (GRBs) which reproduce very well the light curves and spectral evolution of their prompt emission pulses and their smooth afterglows, also reproduce very well the lightcurves and spectral evolution of their X-ray and optical flares. Here we demonstrate that for GRB090812
entry.arxiv:comment: Missing table and references added

entry.title: Gamma-ray emission from pulsar/massive-star binaries
entry.summary: I present a review of the main phenomenological properties at high energies related to massive gamma-ray binaries and I discuss some aspects of pulsar models for these objects.
entry.arxiv:comment: Invited review to the IAU GA JD03, August 2009, to be published in Highlights of Astronomy, T. M. Belloni et al. (eds.), 5 pages

entry.title: Gamma Ray Bursts - Maybe not so old after all
entry.summary: The discovery of a short-lived gamma-ray burst at a surprisingly early epoch in the history of the Universe shows how much is still unknown about the evolution of the parent systems of such bursts.
entry.arxiv:comment: Published in Nature News and Views

entry.title: Magnetic Equilibrium
entry.summary: We propose that generic magnetic equilibrium of an ideally conducting fluid contains a volume-filling set of singular current layers. Singular current layers should exist inside neutron stars. Residual dissipation in the singular current layers might be the main mechanism for the magnetic field decay. The slow decay of the field might be the clock responsible for triggering the magnetar flares.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, 7 figures

entry.title: Advection-Dominated Accretion Disks: Geometrically Slim or Thick?
entry.summary: We revisit the vertical structure of black hole accretion disks in spherical coordinates. By comparing the advective cooling with the viscous heating, we show that advection-dominated disks are geometrically thick, i.e., with the half-opening angle > 2\pi/5, rather than slim as supposed previously in the literature.
entry.arxiv:comment: 12 pages, 3 figures, accepted by PASJ

entry.title: Survey of the Sun in the Lake Baikal Neutrino Experiment
entry.summary: Upward through-going muons in the Lake Baikal Neutrino Experiment arriving from the ecliptic plane have been analyzed using NT200 data samples of the years 1998-2002 (1007 live days). We derive upper limits on muon fluxes from annihilation processes of hypothetical WIMP dark matter particles in the center of the Sun.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, 6 figures, Proceedings of the 31st ICRC, Lodz, Poland, July 2009

entry.title: The Local-Galactic interpretation of the Gamma-Ray Bursts
entry.summary: In this talk, I shall update my 16-year old claim that all the (thousands of) observed GRBs - both long and short, repeating or (so far) not - come from the surfaces of Galactic neutron stars, often called 'magnetars', or 'throttled pulsars'.
entry.arxiv:comment: 13 pages, 3 figures, to be published (possibly shortened) in Chin. J. Astron. Astrophys

entry.title: Measurement of radio emission from extensive air showers
entry.summary: A new promising development in astroparticle physics is to measure the radio emission from extensive air showers. The particles in the cascade emit synchrotron radiation (30 - 90 MHz) which is detected with arrays of dipole antennas. Recent experimental efforts are discussed.
entry.arxiv:comment: invited review at 11th ICATPP

entry.title: Astrophysical Rates for Explosive Nucleosynthesis: Stellar and Laboratory Rates for Exotic Nuclei
entry.summary: A selected overview of stellar effects and reaction mechanisms with relevance to the prediction of astrophysical reaction rates far off stability is provided.

entry.title: Investigation of the Properties of Galactic Cosmic Rays with the KASCADE-Grande Experiment
entry.summary: The properties of galactic cosmic rays are investigated with the KASCADE-Grande experiment in the energy range between $10^{14}$ and $10^{18}$ eV. Recent results are discussed. They concern mainly the all-particle energy spectrum and the elemental composition of cosmic rays.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proc. RICAP 09, Nucl. Instr. and Meth. in press

entry.title: Statistical analysis of RHESSI GRB database
entry.summary: The Gamma-ray burst (GRB) database based on the data by the RHESSI satellite provides a unique and homogeneous database for future analyses. Here we present preliminary results on the duration and hardness ratio distributions for a sample of 228 GRBs observed with RHESSI.
entry.arxiv:comment: Published in Proceedings of the Swift and GRBs: Unveiling the Relativistic Universe Conference

entry.title: Spectrum and composition of galactic cosmic rays accelerated in supernova remnants
entry.summary: The spectra of high-energy protons and nuclei accelerated by supernova remnant shocks are calculated taking into account magnetic field amplification and Alfvenic drift for different types of SNRs during their evolution. The overall energy spectrum and elemental composition of cosmic rays after propagation through the Galaxy are found.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, 4 figures, talk presented at 31st ICRC, Lodz, Poland, July 2009

entry.title: Self-consistent modeling of pair cascades in the polar cap of a pulsar
entry.summary: Here we briefly report on first results of self-consistent simulation of non-stationary electron-positron cascades in the polar cap of pulsar using specially developed hybrid PIC/Monte-Carlo numerical code. We consider the case of Ruderman-Sutherland cascade -- when particles cannot be extracted from the surface of the neutrons star.
entry.arxiv:comment: 6 pages, 5 figures; 2009 Fermi Symposium eConf Proceedings C091122

entry.title: Unveiling cosmic X-ray/gamma-ray sources from their scattering screen
entry.summary: This Commentary discusses the widespread impact of the milestone 1980 paper by Sunyaev and Titarchuk on Comptonization and points out a new possible application to the temporal broadening of the most distant Gamma Ray Bursts.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages. Invited commentary on Sunyaev and Titarchuk 1980, A&A, 86, 121, their classic paper on Comptonization, for the A&A anniversary issue

entry.title: Numerical Studies of Relativistic Jets
entry.summary: The connection between collimation and acceleration of magnetized relativistic jets is discussed. The focus is on recent numerical simulations which shed light on some longstanding problems.
entry.arxiv:comment: 8 pages, 2 figures. To appear in Proceedings of "Accretion and Ejection in AGN: a Global View" (Como, June 22-26, 2009), ASP Conference Series, Eds: L. Maraschi, G. Ghisellini, R. Della Ceca and F. Tavec

entry.title: Gamma-ray emission from AGNs
entry.summary: Blazars, radio-loud active galactic nuclei with the relativistic jet closely aligned with the line of sight, dominate the extragalactic sky observed at gamma-ray energies, above 100 MeV. We discuss some of the emission properties of these sources, focusing in particular on the "blazar sequence" and the interpretative models of the high-energy emission of BL Lac objects.
entry.arxiv:comment: 8 pages, 4 figures, to appear in the proceedings of the HEPRO II conference, Buenos Aires, October 26-30 2009

entry.title: Quiescence and late time activity in collapsars due to critical angular momentum distributions
entry.summary: Even thought a large amount of long gamma ray bursts (LGRBs) present quiescent periods, their origin remains unclear. In this talk, it is shown how different angular momentum distributions, as a function of the stellar radius), can lead to neutrino luminosity variability and the possibility of quiescent epochs in LGRBs.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proceedings for "The shocking Universe: Gamma-Ray Bursts and High Energy Shock Phenomena in the Universe", Venice 2009

entry.title: Relativistic Jets: Open Problems and Challenges
entry.summary: Outstanding questions in the study of relativistic jets in their various astrophysical settings are discussed in the context of a general dynamical model.
entry.arxiv:comment: 12 pages, to appear in proceedings of workshop on High Energy Phenomena in Relativistic Outflow II, to be published in the International Journal of Modern Physics D, uses ws-ijmpd.cls

entry.title: The ANTARES Deep-Sea Neutrino Telescope: Status and First Results
entry.summary: Various aspects of the construction, operation and calibration of the recently completed deep-sea ANTARES neutrino telescope are described. Some first results obtained with a partial five line configuration are presented, including depth dependence of the atmospheric muon rate, the search for point-like cosmic neutrino sources and the search for dark matter annihilation in the Sun.
entry.arxiv:comment: 8 pages, 16 figures

entry.title: Optical Observations of GRB Afterglows
entry.summary: GRB afterglows are among the best examples of astrophysical sources requiring a true multiwavelength observational approach. Radiation processes and main physical ingredients can only be disentangled with knowledge of their spectral and temporal properties through the largest possible band, i.e. from the X-ray down to radio. We now briefly review some of the most relevant observational findings recently obtained through optical observations.
entry.arxiv:comment: To appear in the proceedings of 'The Shocking Universe', held in Venice on September 14-18, 2009

entry.title: A Search for the Intermediate Subgroup of Gamma-Ray Bursts in the Swift Dataset
entry.summary: We have searched for the third, 'intermediate', subgroup of gamma-ray bursts among nearly 400 gamma-ray bursts observed by the Swift satellite. The standard chi^2 method and F-test were applied which give support for the existence of this subgroup.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, 1 figure. Published in Proceedings of the 6th INTEGRAL/BART Workshop, 26-29 March, 2009.

entry.title: Effects of rotochemical heating on the thermal evolution of superfluid neutron stars
entry.summary: The authors take the rotochemical heating effect into account, which may make the cooling scenario different. Their model is consistent with the observation data.
entry.arxiv:comment: 7 pages, 2 figures. To appear in Proceedings for "Compact stars in the QCD phase diagram II (CSQCD II), May 20-24, 2009, KIAA at Peking University, Beijing - P. R. China [http://vega.bac.pku.edu.cn/rxxu/csqcd.htm]

entry.title: Astrophysical Reaction Rates as a Challenge for Nuclear Reaction Theory
entry.summary: The relevant energy ranges for stellar nuclear reactions are introduced. Low-energy compound and direct reactions are discussed. Stellar modifications of the cross sections are presented. Implications for experiments are outlined.
entry.arxiv:comment: 8 pages, 2 figures; invited talk at OMEG10, March 2010. To appear in the OMEG10 proceedings published by AIP

entry.title: Accretion disks
entry.summary: In this lecture the basic theory of accretion disks is reviewed, with emphasis on aspects relevant for X-ray binaries and Cataclysmic Variables. The text gives a general introduction as well as a selective discussion of a number of more recent topics.
entry.arxiv:comment: 49p. To appear in XXI Canary Islands Winter School of Astrophysics, ed. T. Shahbaz, CUP (significantly improved, expanded and updated version of an earlier text)

entry.title: Magnetic acceleration of relativistic jets
entry.summary: This is a brief review of the recent developments in the theory of magnetic acceleration of relativistic jets. We attempt to explain the key results of this complex theory using basic physical arguments and simple calculations. The main focus is on the standard model, which describes steady-state axisymmetric ideal MHD flows. We argue that this model is over-restrictive and discuss various alternatives.
entry.arxiv:comment: Submitted to conference proceedings. "Steady Jets and Transient Jets", Bonn, Germany, 7-8 April 2010

entry.title: Two Dimensional Simulations of Pair-Instability Supernovae
entry.summary: We present preliminary results from two dimensional numerical studies of pair instability supernova (PSN). We study nuclear burning, hydrodynamic instabilities and explosion of very massive stars. Use a new radiation-hydrodynamics code, CASTRO.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proceedings of "The First Stars and Galaxies: Challenges for the Next Decade", Austin, Texas, March 8-11, 2010. 2 pages, 1 figure

entry.title: Lag-luminosity relation in gamma-ray burst X-ray flares
entry.summary: In strict analogy to prompt pulses, X-ray flares observed by Swift-XRT in long Gamma-Ray Bursts define a lag-luminosity relation: L_p,iso \propto t_lag^{-0.95+/-0.23}. The lag-luminosity is proven to be a fundamental law extending 5 decades in time and 5 in energy. This is direct evidence that GRB X-ray flares and prompt gamma-ray pulses are produced by the same mechanism.
entry.arxiv:comment: To appear in: "Deciphering the ancient universe with GRBs", Kyoto 2010, conference proceeding

entry.title: Recent results and perspectives on cosmic rays ground experiments
entry.summary: I summarize in this paper the results and perspectives of representative ground experiments for the observation of very high energy cosmic rays.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, proceedings of IFAE2010, typos corrected

entry.title: Corotating light cylinders and Alfvén waves
entry.summary: Exact relativistic force free fields with cylindrical symmetry are explored. Such fields are generated in the interstellar gas via their connection to pulsar magnetospheres both inside and outside their light cylinders. The possibility of much enhanced interstellar fields wound on cylinders of Solar system dimensions is discussed but these are most likely unstable.
entry.arxiv:comment: 6 pages, 6 figures, accepted by MNRAS

entry.title: Rising indications for three gamma-ray burst groups
entry.summary: Several papers were written about the gamma-ray burst (GRBs) groups. Our statistical study is based on the durations and hardness ratios of the Swift and RHESSI data.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages, 1 figure, 1 table
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Published in SIF Conference Proceedings, Vol. 102, p. 571, The Shocking Universe - Gamma Ray Bursts and High Energy Shock Phenomena, Editors: G. Chincarini, P. D'Avanzo, R. Margutti, R. Salvaterra, Bologna, 2010

entry.title: A comparison of the fluences and photon peak fluxes for the Swift and RHESSI gamma-ray bursts
entry.summary: Fluences and photon peak fluxes of the gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) detected by the Swift and RHESSI satellites are graphically compared.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages, 1 figure
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Published in SIF Conference Proceedings, Vol. 102, p. 527, The Shocking Universe - Gamma Ray Bursts and High Energy Shock Phenomena, Editors: G. Chincarini, P. D'Avanzo, R. Margutti, R. Salvaterra, Bologna, 2010

entry.title: Cold quark matter in astrophysics of compact stars
entry.summary: The appearance of quark matter in the centers of compact stars has a number of astrophysical implications. In this contribution I discuss the structure and stability of compact stars, gravitational radiation from non-axisymmetric deformations, and nucleation and dynamics of vortices (flux tubes) in the color superconducting phases.
entry.arxiv:comment: 8 pages, 2 figures, contribution to the proceedings of QCD@Work, June 20-23rd, 2010, Martina Franca, Italy

entry.title: Asteroseismology of Vibration Powered Neutron Stars
entry.summary: Chapter from the book "Astrophysics", p.287-308. Edited by Ibrahim Kucuk, ISBN 978-953-51-0473-5, InTech, March 3, 2012.
entry.arxiv:comment: http://cdn.intechopen.com/pdfs/34269/InTech-Asteroseismology_of_vibration_powered_neutron_stars.pdf

entry.title: Status of Air Shower Simulations
entry.summary: The present status of extensive air shower (EAS) simulation procedures is reviewed. The advantages of combining numerical and Monte Carlo methods for the description of EAS development are discussed. Physics content of cosmic ray interaction models is briefly described and their predictions are compared to the first LHC data. Finally, some outstanding puzzles related to cosmic ray composition at the "ankle" energies are analyzed.
entry.arxiv:comment: Prepared for 'ARENA-2010'

entry.title: Propagation of thermonuclear flame in SNIa
entry.summary: The propagation of thermonuclear flame in presupernovae Ia is considered. Front parameters are obtained, some speculations on front stability are presented.
entry.arxiv:comment: 6 pages, 2 figures, to appear in Proceedings of XI Symposium on Nuclei in the Cosmos, July 19-23, 2010 Heidelberg, Germany. Presented at NIC-XI poster session

entry.title: Ultra high energy cosmic rays: A review
entry.summary: We present the main results on the energy spectrum and composition of the highest energy cosmic rays of energy exceeding 10$^{18}$ eV obtained by the High Resolution Fly's Eye and the Southern Auger Observatory. The current results are somewhat contradictory and raise interesting questions about the origin and character of these particles.
entry.arxiv:comment: 12 pages, 6 figures, presented at the 2010 Vulcano workshop, Vulcano, Italy

entry.title: Why the knee at 100 PeV could not be seen?
entry.summary: It is shown that a "second (iron) knee" in cosmic ray spectrum expected at energy about 100 PeV could not probably be found there. The reason is very simple: the position of the "iron knee" depends on an answer to the questions: "What do we see at 3-5 PeV? Is the knee seen at this energy associated with proton or iron primaries?"
entry.arxiv:comment: 3 pages, 2 figures. Talk given for 22nd ECRS, Turku'2010

entry.title: Search for a neutrino flux from LS I +61 303 based on a time dependent model with IceCube
entry.summary: We present a search based on a time dependent neutrino flux prediction from the X-ray binary LS I +61 303. Results from data taken with the 22 and 40 strings of IceCube are compatible with background fluctuations.

author.name: Levent Demirörs for the IceCube Collaboration

entry.arxiv:comment: 1 page, for the Proceedings of the Neutrino 2010 Conference, Athens, Greece

entry.title: Asymptotic theory of relativistic, magnetized jets
entry.summary: The structure of a relativistically hot, strongly magnetized jet is investigated at large distances from the source. Asymptotic equations are derived describing collimation and acceleration of the externally confined jet. Conditions are found for the transformation of the thermal energy into the fluid kinetic energy or into the Poynting flux. Simple scalings are presented for the jet collimation angle and Lorentz factors.
entry.arxiv:comment: To appear in Phys.RevE

entry.title: Simple Model of Propagating Flame Pulsations
entry.summary: A simple model which exhibits dynamical flame properties in 1D is presented. It is investigated analytically and numerically. The results are applicable to problems of flame propagation in supernovae Ia.
entry.arxiv:comment: 10 pages, 8 figures, revised version accepted by MNRAS

entry.title: Two temperature accretion flows around rotating black holes and determining the kerr parameter of sources
entry.summary: We model two temperature viscous accretion flows in the sub-Keplerian, optically thin, regime around rotating black holes including important radiation effects self-consistently. The model successfully explains observed luminosities from ultra-luminous to under-luminous sources and predicts the spin parameter of black holes.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages including a figure; to appear in the proceedings of MG12, Marcel Grossman Meeting, Paris, France, 12-18 July 2009

entry.title: Ohmic Power of Ideal Pulsars
entry.summary: Ideal axisymmetric pulsar magnetosphere is calculated from the standard stationary force-free equation but with a new boundary condition at the equator. The new solution predicts Ohmic heating. About 50% of the Poynting power is dissipated in the equatorial current layer outside the light cylinder, with about 10% dissipated between 1 and 1.5 light cylinder radii. The Ohmic heat presumably goes into radiation, pair production, and acceleration of charges -- in an unknown proportion.
entry.arxiv:comment: 3 pages, 1 figure

entry.title: Standard GRB, Dirty Fireballs, and the Excluded Middle
entry.summary: It is shown that the contribution of faint gamma-ray bursts (GRB) to the total allsky GRB energy flux is small. The allsky flux of GRB appears to be $5.3 \times 10^{-3}$ erg/$\rm cm^2 y$, with little additional component hidden within weak or otherwise undetectable GRB. This significantly constrains physical models of GRB and dirty fireballs, suggesting a rather sharp dichotomy between them should the latter exist.
entry.arxiv:comment: to appear in The Astrophysical Journal

entry.title: Stellar Sources of Gamma-ray Bursts
entry.summary: Correlation analysis of Swift gamma-ray burst coordinates and nearby star locations (catalog Gliese) reveals 4 coincidences with good angular accuracy. The random probability is 4\times 10^{-5}, so evidencing that coincident stars are indeed gamma-ray burst sources. Some additional search of stellar gamma-ray bursts is discussed.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages

entry.title: Cosmic rays and diffuse non-thermal emission in galaxy clusters: an introduction
entry.summary: Recent multifrequency observations contribute to derive a comprehensive picture of the origin and evolution of relativistic particles in galaxy clusters. In this review I briefly discuss theoretical aspects and open problems of this picture.
entry.arxiv:comment: Review talk at the conference "Non-thermal phenomena in colliding galaxy clusters", Nice (France), November 2010. 8 pages, 5 figures, Mem S.A.It. in press

entry.title: Radius and magnetic field from Synchrotron-self-absorbed radio and Inverse Compton X-ray observations of Supernovae
entry.summary: Simple expressions for the radius and magnetic field of a system emitting Synchrotron-self-absorbed radio and Inverse Compton X-rays are derived from first principles which involve observable quantities only. These expressions are useful for analyzing observations of Supernova blastwaves interacting with dense circumstellar material at early times.
entry.arxiv:comment: 1 page

entry.title: Fundamental physics from black holes, neutron stars and gamma-ray bursts
entry.summary: Gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) and supernovae (SNe) bring new perspectives to the study of neutron stars and white dwarfs, as well as opening new branches of theoretical physics and astrophysics.
entry.arxiv:comment: 83 pages, 47 figures, to appear in the Proceedings of the Twelfth Marcel Grossmann Meeting on General Relativity

entry.title: Diffuse Neutrino Flux
entry.summary: The search for a diffuse neutrino flux component from astrophysical sources complements searches for point sources. In 2010 and 2011 many new results have been published on this subject. Realistic models can now be tested with these new measurements from the leading neutrino telescope experiments. An overview over these recent results is given.
entry.arxiv:comment: Contribution to Conference Proceedings of XIV International Workshop on "Neutrino Telescopes", Venice 2011

entry.title: The Swift/XRT Catalogue of GRBs
entry.summary: We present the preliminary analysis of the GRB light curves obtained by Swift/XRT between November 2004 and December 2010.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, 4 figures, Poster presented in "The X-ray Universe 2011" Conference, Berlin, 27-30 June 2011

entry.title: Arrival Directions of Ultrahigh Energy Showers Arrival Directions of Ultrahigh Energy Showers
entry.summary: Arrival directions of ultrahigh energy extensive air showers (EAS) by world arrays data are analyzed. It is shown that arrival directions of ultrahigh energy EAS by Yakutsk and P. Auger data are some correlated with pulsars of Local Arm Orion of Galaxy. It is found large amplitude of first harmony of Fourier row by data Yakutsk array. The problem of cosmic rays origin is discussed.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, 5 figures

entry.title: Cosmic ray acceleration at oblique shocks
entry.summary: We show that the diffusion approximation breaks down for particle acceleration at oblique shocks with velocities typical of young supernova remnants. Higher order anisotropies flatten the spectral index at quasi-parallel shocks and steepen the spectral index at quasi-perpendicular shocks. We compare the theory with observed spectral indices.
entry.arxiv:comment: 11 pages, 4 figures, 1 table. Accepted for publication in Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society

entry.title: An adjustable law of motion for relativistic spherical shells
entry.summary: A classical and a relativistic law of motion for an advancing shell are deduced applying the thin layer approximation. A new parameter connected with the quantity of absorbed matter in the expansion is introduced; this allows of matching theory and observation.
entry.arxiv:comment: 15 pages, 10 figures and article in press; Central European Journal of Physics 2011

entry.title: Isolated neutron stars and studies of their interiors
entry.summary: In these lectures presented at Baikal summer school on physics of elementary particles and astrophysics 2011, I present a wide view of neutron star astrophysics with special attention paid to young isolated compact objects and studies of the properties of neutron star interiors using astronomical methods.
entry.arxiv:comment: 28 pages, lecture notes for the Baikal-2011 summer school on physics of elementary particles and astrophysics

entry.title: Of Winds and Waves
entry.summary: Recent work on the properties of superluminal waves in pulsar winds is summarized. It is speculated that these waves play an important role in the termination shock that divides the wind from the surrounding nebula.
entry.arxiv:comment: Invited talk at the 11th Asian-Pacific Regional IAU Meeting, July 2011, Chiang Mai, Thailand
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Proc 11th Asian-Pacific Regional IAU Meeting, Ed: Komonjinda, S., Kovalev, Y.Y., Ruffolo, D., NARIT Conference Series Vol.\ 1, pp241--245 (2013)

entry.title: The IceCube Neutrino Observatory III: Cosmic Rays
entry.arxiv:comment: Papers submitted by the IceCube Collaboration to the 32nd International Cosmic Ray Conference, Beijing 2011; part III

entry.title: The IceCube Neutrino Observatory II: All Sky Searches: Atmospheric, Diffuse and EHE
entry.arxiv:comment: Papers submitted by the IceCube Collaboration to the 32nd International Cosmic Ray Conference, Beijing 2011; part II

entry.title: The IceCube Neutrino Observatory IV: Searches for Dark Matter and Exotic Particles
entry.summary: Exotic particle searches: WIMPs annihilating in the Sun, in the galactic center, in nearby dwarf galaxies; magnetic monopoles; Submitted papers to the 32nd International Cosmic Ray Conference, Beijing 2011.
entry.arxiv:comment: Papers submitted by the IceCube Collaboration to the 32nd International Cosmic Ray Conference, Beijing 2011; part IV

entry.title: The IceCube Neutrino Observatory I: Point Source Searches
entry.summary: Searches for point sources of astrophysical neutrinos and related measurements: Searches for steady and time-variable sources; Follow-up programs; AGNs; GRBs; Moon shadow; Submitted papers to the 32nd International Cosmic Ray Conference, Beijing 2011.
entry.arxiv:comment: Papers submitted by the IceCube Collaboration to the 32nd International Cosmic Ray Conference, Beijing 2011; part I

entry.title: The Shadow of the Moon in IceCube
entry.summary: IceCube is the world's largest neutrino telescope, recently completed at the South Pole. As a proof of pointing accuracy, we look for the image of the Moon as a deficit in down-going cosmic ray muons, using techniques similar to those used in IceCube's astronomical point-source searches.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, 4 figures, Proceedings of the XLVI Rencontres de Moriond, International Conference on Electroweak Interactions and Unified Theories, La Thuile, Italy, Mar. 20-27, 2011

entry.title: Optical pulsations from isolated neutron stars
entry.summary: Being fast rotating objects, isolated neutron stars (INSs) are obvious targets for high-time resolution observations. With the number of optical/UV/IR INS detections now increased to 24, timing observations become more and more important in INS astrophysics.

author.name: R. P. Mignani
author.arxiv:affiliation: MSSL-UCL, Kepler Institute of Astronomy, University of Zielona Gora

entry.arxiv:comment: 3 pages, to appear in Proc. IAU 285, "New Horizons in Transient Astronomy", Oxford, Sept. 2011

entry.title: Fluctuations of the depth of maximum in extensive air showers and cross-section of p-air inelastic interaction for energy range 10^15-10^17 eV
entry.summary: We present estimation of proton-air inelastic interaction cross-section obtained for different energy values are. Results are compared with different hadron interaction models.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proc. 32nd ICRC, Aug. 11-18, Beijing, China

entry.title: Particles Flux of Ultrahigh Energy from a Galactic Plane
entry.summary: Arrival directions of particles were analyzed according to the arrays of extensive air showers (EAS) data. A new method of sources search and anisotropy of arrival directions particles is suggested. There was found the particles flux of ultrahigh energy from the galactic plane that exceeds the expected number of particles in the case of isotropy more than 4\sigma and 5\sigma.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 page, 2 Fig

entry.title: High Energy Neutrinos from Space
entry.summary: This paper reviews the status of the search for high-energy neutrinos from astrophysical sources. Results from large neutrino telescopes in water (Antares, Baikal) and ice (IceCube) are discussed as well as observations from the surface with Auger and from high altitude with ANITA. Comments on IceTop, the surface component of IceCube are also included.
entry.arxiv:comment: 16 pages, 10 figures for Proceedings of Lepton-Photon 2011, Mumbai India, to appear in a special issue of Pramana - Journal of physics

entry.title: Neutrinos and cosmic rays
entry.summary: In this paper we review the status of the search for high-energy neutrinos from outside the solar system and discuss the implications for the origin and propagation of cosmic rays. Connections between neutrinos and gamma-rays are also discussed.
entry.arxiv:comment: 25 pages, 5 figures, for a topical issue of Astroparticle Physics on cosmic rays

entry.title: Sources of GeV Photons and the Fermi Results
entry.summary: This is a pedagological review of some astrophysical highlights of the Fermi Gamma ray Observatory, including theoretical studies related mainly to extragalactic Fermi science.
entry.arxiv:comment: 137 pages, 35 figures; draft of book chapter in Astrophysics at Very-High Energies, 40th Saas-Fee Advanced Course. Comments welcome

entry.title: Shower Center of Gravity and Hadronic Interaction Characteristics
entry.summary: Equations for the center of gravity of the shower originated by high energy proton in the atmosphere are written and, within certain simplifications, solved for the case of logarithmically decreasing interaction length of hadrons in the air. Obtained expression provides transparent view of the way in which hadronic interaction characteristics determine the longitudinal shower development.

entry.title: Fermi Gamma-Ray Burst Monitor Science Highlights
entry.summary: Three years after the launch of the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope, both of its scientific instruments are operating perfectly and continuing to make breakthroughs in astrophysics, particle physics, and atmospheric science. I report here on the highlights of the scientific program of the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor (GBM).
entry.arxiv:comment: to appear in ICRC 2011

entry.title: Early evolution of spherical ejecta expanding into the circumstellar matter at ultra-relativistic speeds
entry.summary: We present a new self-similar solution describing early evolution of an ultra-relativistic flow resulting from a collision of homologously expanding spherical ejecta with the circumstellar matter, in which a shock wave propagates in the circumstellar matter while a weak discontinuity propagates in the ejecta at the sound speed
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, 2 figures, accepted for publication in PASJ

entry.title: Near stellar sources of gamma-ray bursts
entry.summary: Correlation analysis of gamma-ray burst coordinates and nearby stars, registered on 2008-2011, revealed 5 coincidences with angular accuracy better than 0.1 degree. The random probability is $7\times 10^{-7}$, so evidencing that coincident stars are indeed gamma-ray burst sources. The proposed method should be continued in order to provide their share in common balance of cosmic gamma-ray bursts.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages

entry.title: Neutrinos And Cosmic Rays From Gamma Ray Bursts
entry.summary: The upper limit on the flux of ultra high energy neutrinos from gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) that was reported recently by the IceCube collaboration contradicts predictions based on the Fireball model of GRBs, but does not exclude GRBs as a main source of ultra-high energy cosmic rays.
entry.arxiv:comment: Corrected references

entry.title: Microblazar properties of LSI+61303
entry.summary: In this paper we describe the gamma-ray binary LSI+61303 as a blazar like object, based on variable Doppler boosting and core-shift effect considerations.
entry.arxiv:comment: proceedings of the Meeting "370 years of astronomy in Utrecht", Noordwijkerhout, The Netherlands, April 2-5, 2012 (ASPCS Conference Series)

entry.title: CSS091109:035759+102943 - a candidate polar
entry.summary: We report optical time-resolved photometry of the CRTS transient CSS091109:035759+102943. Pronounced orbital variability with a 114 min period, large X-ray variability and the IR to X-ray spectral energy distribution suggest a classification as a magnetic cataclysmic binary, a likely AM Herculis star or polar.
entry.arxiv:comment: Astronomische Nachrichten, in press (4 pages, 4 figures)

entry.title: CV surveys with eROSITA
entry.summary: eROSITA will perform the most sensitive X-ray all-sky ever in the energy range 0.3 - 10 keV. It will likely uncover several 10^4 compact binaries, most of them will be cataclysmic variable stars. After a brief introduction to eROSITA we will discuss the source content of the eROSITA surveys, the expected number of CVs and possible strategies for the optical follow-up.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proc. 'The Golden Age of CVs', Mem.S.A.It., in press

entry.title: Nonperturbative Quantum Field Theory in Astrophysics
entry.summary: The extreme electromagnetic or gravitational fields associated with some astrophysical objects can give rise to macroscopic effects arising from the physics of the quantum vacuum. Therefore, these objects are incredible laboratories for exploring the physics of quantum field theories. In this dissertation, we explore this idea in three astrophysical scenarios.
entry.arxiv:comment: PhD Thesis, 289 pages

entry.title: Pulsar Efficiency
entry.summary: Pulsar efficiency, defined as the ratio of the pulsed bolometric luminosity to the spin-down power, is calculated to be about 15% (averaged over the spin-dipole inclination angle, ranging between about 50% for the aligned and 10% for the orthogonal). We also estimate the characteristic photon energy and argue that our results agree with the Fermi pulsar catalog -- in a sense.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages, 1 figure

entry.title: Superbubble Origin of Cosmic Rays
entry.summary: After a hundred years of searching for the origin of cosmic rays, where and how they are made has finally become clear. Here we briefly trace that odyssey through both astronomical observations and cosmic ray measurements.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, 3 figures, Invited paper in Centenary Symposium 2012: Discovery of Cosmic Rays (AIP Conf. Proc.)

entry.title: Review of Indirect WIMP Search Experiments
entry.summary: Observational evidence for dark matter can be explained by Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs). These dark matter particle candidates could indirectly be detected through the observation of signals produced as part of WIMP annihilations or decays. Latest results from indirect searches for WIMPs are reviewed. Current and planned experiments are presented and their prospects and discovery potential discussed.
entry.arxiv:comment: 8 pages, 11 figures, Proceedings for the XXV International Conference on Neutrino Physics and Astrophysics (Neutrino 2012), June 2012, Kyoto, Japan

entry.title: Radiation Properties of GeV Narrow Line Seyfert 1 Galaxies
entry.summary: The broadband SEDs of four gamma-ray NLS1s are compiled and explained with the leptonic model. It is found that their characteristics and fitting parameters of the observed SEDs are more like FSRQs than BL Lacs.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages; 1 figure; to appear in the proceedings of the IAU Symposium 290, "Feeding compact objects: accretion on all scales", Beijing, 20-24 Aug 2012

entry.title: The complex charm of the pulsar magnetosphere
entry.summary: I give a brief overview of recent results from self-consistent modeling of electron-positrons cascades in pulsar polar caps. These results strongly suggest that the pulsar magnetosphere is a more complex system than was assumed before.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proceedings of IAUS 291 "Neutron Stars and Pulsars: Challenges and Opportunities after 80 years", J. van Leeuwen (ed.); 6 pages, 2 figures

entry.title: Cosmic-ray Spectrum and Composition with the IceCube Observatory
entry.summary: This paper reports on recent results from measurements of energy spectrum and nuclear composition of galactic cosmic rays performed with the IceCube Observatory at the South Pole in the energy range between about 300 TeV and 1 EeV.
entry.arxiv:comment: To Appear in the Proceedings of 13th Marcel Grossmann Meeting (Stockholm, Sweden, 2012)

entry.title: CTA contributions to the 2012 Heidelberg Symposium on High Energy Gamma-Ray Astronomy
entry.summary: Compilation of CTA contributions to the proceedings of the 2012 Heidelberg Symposium on High Energy Gamma-Ray Astronomy (Gamma 2012), which took place in July 9-13, 2012, in Heidelberg, Germany
entry.arxiv:comment: Index of CTA conference proceedings at the Gamma 2012, Heidelberg. v1: placeholder with no arXiv links yet. v2: final with arXiv links to all CTA contributions

entry.title: Glitches detected in southern radio pulsars
entry.summary: Parkes pulse arrival-time data for 165 radio pulsars spanning from 1990 to 2011 have been searched for period glitches. Forty-six events out of the detected 107 glitches were found to be new contributions to the entire glitch population which currently contains approximately 400 events.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proceedings of IAUS 291 "Neutron Stars and Pulsars: Challenges and Opportunities after 80 years", J. van Leeuwen (ed.); 3 pages, 3 figures

entry.title: Highlights in astroparticle physics: muons, neutrinos, hadronic interactions, exotic particles, and dark matter --- Rapporteur Talk HE2 & HE3
entry.summary: Recent results presented at the International Cosmic Ray Conference in Beijing will be reviewed. Topics include HE2: "Muons and Neutrinos" and HE3: "Interactions, Particle Physics Aspects, Cosmology"
entry.arxiv:comment: Invited rapporteur talk at the ICRC in Beijing. The article is from earlier this year, but could be uploaded only now due to technical reasons

entry.title: Recent results from the ANTARES deep sea neutrino telescope
entry.summary: The ANTARES deep sea neutrino telescope has acquired over four years of high quality data. This data has been used to measure the oscillation parameters of atmospheric neutrinos and also to search for neutrinos of a non-terrestrial origin. Competitive upper limits on the fluxes of neutrinos from dark matter annihilation in the Sun, a variety of Galactic and extra-galactic sources, both steady and transient, are presented.

entry.title: Global structure of the pulsar force-free magnetosphere revisited
entry.summary: A new model of the pulsar force-free magnetosphere is suggested, which includes the presence of the polar, outer and slot gaps. It is based on a new exact solution of the pulsar equation in the form of an offset monopole and the resultant split-offset monopole scheme.
entry.arxiv:comment: 3 pages, 2 figures; to appear in Proceedings of IAUS 291 "Neutron Stars and Pulsars: Challenges and Opportunities after 80 years", J. van Leeuwen (ed.)

entry.title: Powerful relativistic jets in narrow-line Seyfert 1 galaxies
entry.summary: The recent detection of high-energy gamma rays from Narrow-Line Seyfert 1 Galaxies has confirmed that also this type of active galactic nuclei can generate powerful relativistic jets. I outline the evolution of the knowledge in this research field and the implications on the unification of relativistic jets at all scales.
entry.arxiv:comment: 13 pages, 2 figures. Proceedings of the Conference "Nuclei of Seyfert galaxies and QSOs - Central engine & conditions of star formation" (Bonn, Germany, 6-8 November 2012)

entry.title: Ultra-compact binaries: relevance and role of Utrecht
entry.summary: We present a short overview of the formation and evolution of ultra-compact binaries. They are relevant to a surprisingly large number of astrophysical phenomena (binary interactions, mass transfer stability, explosive phenomena such as type Ia supernovae and gravitational waves).
entry.arxiv:comment: To appear in proceedings of "370 years of astronomy in Utrecht", Noordwijkerhout, The Netherlands, April 2-5, 2012 (ASP Conference Series)

entry.title: A Search for Gamma-Ray Emission from Variable or Transient Galactic Radio Sources
entry.summary: We describe an ongoing effort using the Fermi Large Area Telescope to search for gamma-ray emission from a source sample derived from published surveys of variable or transient galactic radio sources.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2012 Fermi Symposium proceedings - eConf C121028

entry.title: Pulse profiles from thermally emitting neutron stars
entry.summary: The problem of computing the pulse profiles from thermally emitting spots on the surface of a neutron star in general relativity is reconsidered. We show that it is possible to extend Beloborodov (2002) approach to include (multiple) spots of finite size in different positions on the star surface. Results for the pulse profiles are expressed by comparatively simple analytical formulas which involve only elementary functions.
entry.arxiv:comment: 8 pages, 6 figures, accepted for publication in ApJ

entry.title: The problem of small angular scale structure in the cosmic ray anisotropy data
entry.summary: Recent observations have revealed structure on small angular scales in the anisotropy data of cosmic rays at multi TeV energies. Even though the absolute amplitudes are very small, these effects are somewhat surprising and a wide range of possible causes have been discussed. A possible origin associated with heliospheric electric fields is proposed.
entry.arxiv:comment: To be presented at the International Cosmic Ray Conference ICRC32013 in Rio

entry.title: Ice Cube Observed PeV Neutrinos from AGN Cores
entry.summary: I show that the high energy neutrino flux predicted to arise from AGN cores can explain the PeV neutrinos detected by Ice Cube without conflicting with the constraints from the observed extragalactic cosmic ray and gamma-ray backgrounds.
entry.arxiv:comment: version to be published in Phys. Rev. D

entry.title: Antiglitch Inconsistent With Magnetar Model of AXP
entry.summary: The recently observed antiglitch of AXP 1E 2259+586 is inconsistent with magnetar models, but may be explained as the consequence of sudden accretion of retrograde matter or "propeller" interaction with surrounding matter. AXP/SGR are explained as single neutron stars accompanied by fallback matter from their natal supernovae. Their phenomenology may be partly accretional and partly the result of dissipation of magnetic energy.
entry.arxiv:comment: 11 pages, 0 figures, references added

entry.title: I. Inverse Compton origin of pulsar γ-ray emission. II. Reconnection model of Crab flares
entry.summary: I. There is growing evidence that pulsars' high energy emission is generated via Inverse Compton mechanism. II. The particles producing Crab flares, and possibly most of the Crab Nebula's high energy emission, are accelerated via reconnection events, and not at shock via Fermi mechanisms.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proceedings, XMM-Newton Science Workshop "Fast and Furious", 6 pages

entry.title: ASTRI contributions to the 33rd International Cosmic Ray Conference (ICRC-2013)
entry.summary: Compilation of ASTRI contributions to the proceedings of the 33rd International Cosmic Ray Conference (ICRC2013), which took place in 2-9 July, 2013, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
entry.arxiv:comment: Index of ASTRI conference proceedings at the ICRC2013, Rio de Janeiro (Brazil). v1: placeholder with no arXiv links yet, to be replaced once individual contributions have been all submitted

entry.title: IceCube: Neutrino Physics from GeV - PeV
entry.summary: An update on recent discoveries by the IceCube project, which transforms approximately one cubic kilometer of natural Antarctic ice into a Cherenkov detector. This paper will be submitted to SLAC for inclusion in the Snowmass2013 proceedings
entry.arxiv:comment: 3 pages, 2 figures, submitted as a Snowmass white paper

entry.title: Testing Relativity with High-Energy Astrophysical Neutrinos
entry.summary: The recent observation of high-energy astrophysical neutrinos can be used to constrain violations of Lorentz invariance emerging from a quantum theory of gravity. We perform threshold and Cherenkov analyses that improve existing bounds by factors ranging from about a million to 10^{20}.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages two-column REVTeX

entry.title: Quasi-periodic oscillations from Rossby Wave Instability
entry.summary: We study the Rossby wave instability model of high-frequency quasi-periodic oscillations (QPO) of microquasars. We show ray-traced light curves of QPO within this model and discuss perspectives of distinguishing alternative QPO models with the future Large Observatory For X-ray Timing (LOFT) observations.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proceedings of the French Astronomical Society 2013 Meeting

entry.title: Chandra Imaging of Gamma-Ray Binaries
entry.summary: We review the multiwavelength properties of the few known gamma-ray binaries, focusing on extended emission recently resolved with Chandra. We discuss the implications of these findings for the nature of compact objects and for physical processes operating in these systems.
entry.arxiv:comment: 6 pages, 4 figures, 2 tables, procedings of XMM-Newton 2013 Science Workshop, to be published in Astronomische Nachrichten

entry.title: The unification of relativistic jets
entry.summary: I report about the unification of relativistic jets from compact objects. The mass range is between 1.4 and 10 billion solar masses (i.e. from neutron stars to supermassive black holes in galaxies).
entry.arxiv:comment: 6 pages, 1 figure. Proceedings HEPROIV (Heidelberg, Germany, 23-26 July 2013). Some typo fixed. To be published on International Journal of Modern Physics Conference Series
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: International Journal of Modern Physics: Conference Series, 28, (2014), id. 1460188

entry.title: Microvariability Detection of Mrk 421
entry.summary: The BL Lac object Mrk 421 was observed in optical bands from 2009 April to 2012 May with the 1.0 m telescope at Weihai Observatory of Shandong University. Microvariability was analysed by C and F tests, but no significant microvariability was detected during our observations.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages, 1 figure

entry.title: Measuring chemical composition and particle cross-section of ultra-high energy cosmic rays by a ground radio array
entry.summary: We present a technique to measure chemical composition and particle cross-section of ultra-high energy cosmic rays using radio data. We relate the geometry of the radio footprint on the ground to the depth of the extensive air shower maximum. We suggest to use the spectral information of the radio signal to improve the shower maximum reconstruction by minimum number of antennas on the ground.

entry.title: The surface and inner temperatures of magnetars
entry.summary: Assuming that the timescale of the magnetic field decay is approximately equal to that of the stellar cooling via neutrino emission, we obtain a one-to-one relationship between the effective surface thermal temperature and the inner temperature. The ratio of the effective neutrino luminosity to the effective X-ray luminosity decreases with decaying magnetic field.
entry.arxiv:comment: 3 Pages, 3 Figures, Published in IAU Symposium, 2013, V.291 p.386-388. 2013IAU Symposium

entry.title: To the Origin of Anomalous Torque Acting on a Rotating Magnetized Ball in Vacuum
entry.summary: The magnitude of the anomalous torque acting on a rotating magnetized ball in vacuum is specified. Its value is shown to depend on the magnetic field structure inside the body.
entry.arxiv:comment: With some corrections
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Bulletin of the Lebedev Physics Institute, 2013, Vol. 40, No. 9, pp. 265-267

entry.title: 3C 273 - half a century later
entry.summary: We have presented an optical monitoring of 3C 273, the first quasar discovered fifty years ago. It does not show variability both on intra-night and long-term time scales. To facilitate the further monitoring of 3C 273, we compiled the available calibrations of the comparison stars in its field into a mean sequence.

entry.title: Indirect searches for dark matter with the Fermi LAT instrument
entry.summary: In this review the current status of several searches for particle dark matter with the Fermi Large Area Telescope instrument is presented. In particular, the current limits on the weakly interacting massive particles, obtained from the analyses of gamma-rays and cosmic-ray electron/positron data, will be illustrated.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proceeding of the 2013 Lepton Photon Conference; 22 pages; 11 figures

entry.title: $pγ$ interactions in Galactic jets as a plausible origin of the positron excess
entry.summary: The positron flux measured near Earth shows a rise with energy beyond 30 GeV. We show that this rise may be compatible with the production of positrons in $p \gamma$ interactions in the jets of microquasars.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, 1 figure, to be published in MNRAS

entry.title: Perytons and their Possible Sources
entry.summary: Perytons are terrestrial signals that exhibit dispersion measure (DM) similar to pulsars. In trying to identify terrestrial sources of such perytons, investigation into signals from airborne equipment (aircraft), RFI emissions from electronics and lightning phenomenon reveals that the possible sources of perytons could be lightning phenomenon. Narrow Bipolar Pulses (NBPs) and Terrestrial Gamma Flashes (TGFs) are good investigational candidates.
entry.arxiv:comment: 7 pages, 1 table, 1 figure

entry.title: Converting Neutron Stars into Strange Stars: Instanton Model
entry.summary: We estimate the quasiclassical probability of the homogeneous nuclear matter transition to a strange matter when a detonation wave propagates radially inside a sphere of nuclear matter. For this purpose we make use of instanton method which is known in the quantum field theory.
entry.arxiv:comment: 9 pages, 3 Figures

entry.title: An extended universality of electron distributions in cosmic ray showers of high energies and its application
entry.summary: It is shown that the shape of any electron distribution in a high energy air shower is the same in all such showers, if taken at the same age, independently of the primary energy, mass and thus, of the interaction model.
entry.arxiv:comment: subbmitted to Astroparticle Physics; accepted

entry.title: Time variability of the $γ$-ray binary HESS J0632+057
entry.summary: We study changes in the $\gamma$--ray intensity at very high energies observed from the $\gamma$--ray binary HESS J0632+057. Publicly available data collected by Cherenkov telescopes were examined by means of a simple method utilizing solely the number of source and background events. Our results point to time variability in signal from the selected object consistent with periodic modulation of the source intensity.

entry.title: On the anomalous torque applied to a rotating magnetized sphere in a vacuum
entry.summary: We analyze the torque applied to a rotating magnetized sphere in a vacuum. It is shown that for the correct determination of one of the torque's component the angular momentum of the electromagnetic field within the body should be taken into account.
entry.arxiv:comment: 10 pages

entry.title: Overview of ANTARES results on Dark Matter Searches
entry.summary: The search for dark matter is one of the most important goals of neutrino telescopes. The ANTARES detector, installed in the Mediterranean Sea, is taking data since 2007. Neutrino telescopes have interesting advantages for this kind of searches, as it will be discussed. In this talk we will review the status and results of the analyses performed in ANTARES for several sources: the Sun, Galactic Centre and the Earth.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proceedings of 2014 Moriond-Cosmology conference, ISBN 978-2-9546400-5-1

entry.title: Spectra of Astrophysical Particles at Ultra High Energy and the Auger Data
entry.summary: We use a kinetic-equation approach to describe the propagation of ultra high energy cosmic ray protons and nuclei comparing theoretical results with the observations of the Pierre Auger Observatory.
entry.arxiv:comment: 10 pages, 4 eps figures, to appear in the Proceedings of the VULCANO Workshop 2014, "Frontier Objects in Astrophysics and Particle Physics", Frascati Physics Series Vol. 58 (2014)

entry.title: Cosmic Rays: What Gamma Rays Can Say
entry.summary: We will review the main channels of gamma ray emission due to the acceleration and propagation of cosmic rays, discussing the cases of both galactic and extra-galactic cosmic rays and their connection with gamma rays observations.
entry.arxiv:comment: 10 pages, 6 pdf figures, to appear in the proceedings of the workshop "Science with the New Generation of High Energy Gamma-ray experiments", 10th Workshop - Scineghe2014 - 04-06 June 2014, Lisbon Portugal

entry.title: On the continuum radio-spectrum of Cas A: possible evidence of the non-linear particle acceleration
entry.summary: Integrated radio-spectrum of Cas A in continuum was analyzed with special emphasis on possible high frequency spectral curvature. We conclude that the most probable scenario is that Planck's new data reveal the imprint of non-linear particle acceleration in the case of this young Galactic supernova remnant (SNR).
entry.arxiv:comment: Accepted by ApJ

entry.title: Two predictions for the spin down behavior of magnetar SGR J1745-2900
entry.summary: The basic concepts of wind braking of magnetars, and its applications to various timing events of magnetars are outlined. The case of the Galactic centre magnetar SGR J1745-2900 is especially discussed. Two predictions for SGR J1745-2900 are made (the period derivative will first increase then decrease; and possible outbursts in the near future).
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, submitted to proceeding of Quarks and Compact Stars 2014, Beijing

entry.title: Acceleration of cosmic rays and gamma-ray emission from supernova remnant/molecular cloud associations
entry.summary: The gamma-ray observations of molecular clouds associated with supernova remnants are considered one of the most promising ways to search for a solution of the problem of cosmic ray origin. Here we briefly review the status of the field, with particular emphasis on the theoretical and phenomenological aspects of the problem.
entry.arxiv:comment: Invited talk at SUGAR2015

entry.title: Type IIn supernovae as sources of high energy neutrinos
entry.summary: It is shown that high-energy astrophysical neutrinos observed in the IceCube experiment can be produced by protons accelerated in extragalactic Type IIn supernova remnants by shocks propagating in the dense circumstellar medium. The nonlinear diffusive shock acceleration model is used for description of particle acceleration.
entry.arxiv:comment: 9 pages, 4 figures, oral talk at 34th ICRC, Hague, Netherlands 30July-06Aug 2015

entry.title: AGN Flickering and Chaotic Accretion
entry.summary: Observational arguments suggest that the growth phases of the supermassive black holes in active galactic nuclei have a characteristic timescale $\sim 10^5$ yr. We show that this is the timescale expected in the chaotic accretion picture of black hole feeding, because of the effect of self-gravity in limiting the mass of any accretion disc feeding event.
entry.arxiv:comment: 3 pages. Accepted for publication in MNRAS Letters

entry.title: ALP hints from cooling anomalies
entry.summary: We review the current status of the anomalies in stellar cooling and argue that, among the new physics candidates, an axion-like particle would represent the best option to account for the hinted additional cooling.
entry.arxiv:comment: Contributed to the 11th Patras Workshop on Axions, WIMPs and WISPs, Zaragoza, June 22 to 26, 2015

entry.title: Coherent Radio Emission from Pulsars
entry.summary: We review a physical model where the high brightness temperature of 10$^{25}-10^{30}$ K observed in pulsar radio emission is explained by coherent curvature radiation excited in the relativistic electron-positron plasma in the pulsar magnetosphere.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, To appear in Recent Trends in the Study of Compact Objects (RETCO-II): Theory and Observation ASI Conference Series, 2015, Vol. 12, pp 1-4 Edited by Indranil Chattopadhyay, Anuj Nandi, Santabrata Das and Samir Mandal

entry.title: Spectral components in black hole X-ray binaries
entry.summary: This paper summarises our current understanding of the spectral continuum components observed in black hole X-ray binaries. The consequences for theoretical models are discussed with an emphasis on the constraints set by observations on the nature of the X-ray corona in different spectral states.
entry.arxiv:comment: 7 pages, 3 figures, invited review at the XMM-Newton 2015 Science Workshop, The Extremes of Black Hole Accretion, ESAC, Madrid, Spain, 8th - 10th June 2015, accepted for publication in Astronomische Nachrichten

entry.title: Bernoulli equation and the nonexistence of maximal jets
entry.summary: We discuss the idea of maximal jets introduced by Falcke & Biermann in 1995. According to it, the maximum possible jet power in its internal energy equals the kinetic power in its rest mass. We show this result is incorrect because of an unfortunate algebraic mistake.
entry.arxiv:comment: A&A, in press

entry.title: Charge-sign dependent solar modulation for everyone
entry.summary: We present a tool to compute the influence of charge-sign dependent solar modulation for cosmic ray spectra. The code is publicly available, easy to use and offers an extended view on solar modulation compared to the force-field approximation. We present some examples for proton and antiproton fluxes in the light of recent experimental data.
entry.arxiv:comment: Contribution to the TAUP 2015 conference proceedings. 5 pages, 4 figures

entry.title: Neutrinos at extreme energies
entry.summary: We will review the production of neutrinos with PeV energies and above. Discussing two possible sources of this radiation: the propagation of ultra high energy cosmic rays and the decay of super heavy dark matter. The discussion will focus on the theoretical expectations on neutrino fluxes and on the detection capabilities of present and future experiments.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, 4 pdf figures, contribution to the proceedings of the TAUP 2015 conference

entry.title: Deeply x-raying the high-energy sky
entry.summary: All-sky explorations by Fermi-LAT have revolutionized our view of the gamma-ray sky. While its ongoing all-sky survey counts thousands of sources, essential issues related to the nature of unassociated sources call for sensitive all-sky surveys at hard X-ray energies that allow for their identification. We present the results of the association of the Fermi-LAT second source catalog to hard X-ray detected sources.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, 4 figures, submitted JPCS

entry.title: Fast Radio Bursts: Searches, Sensitivities & Implications
entry.summary: Fast radio bursts (FRBs) are millisecond-duration transient signals discovered over the past decade. Here we describe the scientific usefulness of FRBs, consider ongoing work at the Parkes telescope, and examine some relevant search sensitivity and completeness considerations. We also look ahead to the results from ongoing and future planned studies in the field.
entry.arxiv:comment: 7 pages, GB1 talk presented at the Marcel Grossmann Meeting (MG14), Rome, July 2015

entry.title: Relativistic low angular momentum accretion in 3D
entry.summary: We study the low angular momentum accretion of matter onto Schwarzschild or Kerr black hole using fully relativistic numerical simulations. Our aim is to include the rotation of both the gas and the black hole and the presence of the magnetic field into the picture. We compare resulting structure of transonic flow with results of 1D pseudo-Newtonian semi-analytical computations of non-magnetized flow.
entry.arxiv:comment: 3 pages, 2 figures

entry.title: Fermi GBM signal contemporaneous with GW150914 - an unlikely association
entry.summary: We argue that the physical constraints required by the association of the Fermi GBM signal contemporaneous with GW150914 - radiative power of $10^{49} $ erg s$^{-1}$, and corresponding magnetic fields on the black hole of the order of $10^{12}$ Gauss - are astrophysical highly implausible. Combined with the relatively high random probability of coincidence of 0.22 percents, we conclude that the electromagnetic signal is likely unrelated to the BH merger.

entry.title: Search for the Giant Pulses Search for the Giant Pulses - an extreme phenomenon in radio pulsar emission
entry.summary: Here we present results of our search for Giant Pulses(GPs) from pulsars of Northern Hemisphere. Our survey was carried out at a frequency of 111 MHz using the Large Phased Array (LPA) radio telescope. Up to now we have detected regular generation of strong pulses satisfying the criteria of GPs from 2 pulsars: B1133+16, B1237+25.
entry.arxiv:comment: 3 pages, 4 figures

entry.title: Black Hole Spindown by Light Bosons
entry.summary: The saturation mechanism for the fastest-growing instability of massive scalar field in Kerr metric is identified, assuming saturation by cubic or quartic nonlinearities of the field potential. The resulting spindown rate of the black hole is calculated. The (rather involved) saturation scenario is confirmed by numerical simulations.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, 2 figures

entry.title: Maxwell equation violation by density dependent magnetic fields in neutron stars
entry.summary: We show that the widely used density dependent magnetic field prescriptions, necessary to account for the variation of the field intensity from the crust to the core of neutron stars violate one of the Maxwell equations. We estimate how strong the violation is when different equations of state are used and check for which cases the pathological problem can be cured.

entry.title: Fireballs from Superconducting Cosmic Strings
entry.summary: Thermalized fireballs should be created by cusp events on superconducting cosmic strings. This simple notion allows to reliably estimate particle emission from the cusps in a given background magnetic field. With plausible assumptions about intergalactic magnetic fields, the cusp events can produce observable fluxes of high-energy photons and neutrinos with unique signatures.
entry.arxiv:comment: 15 pages

entry.title: Neutrino Astrophysics
